ticket.title: Remote forms with multiple submit controls don't report which submit was used, under Unobtrusive JavaScript
ticket.original-body:
(Rails 3.0.0)
Consider a simple view:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
When this is submitted (by normal POST), the parameters includes `"commit" => "Foo"` or `"commit" => "Bar"`.
However, if the form is using unobtrusive javascript to make it an AJAX request:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}, {:remote => true}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
... then the parameters do not carry the submit control which was used. This is because the function `callRemote` in `rails.js` uses `serializeArray` on the form; but `serializeArray` doesn't take account of the control used to submit the form.
I have patched my local app by making use of `originalEvent`, but I have no means of using Git (my corporate firewall blocks the SSH port). How can I get my patch considered?
ticket.latest-body:
(Rails 3.0.0)
Consider a simple view:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
When this is submitted (by normal POST), the parameters includes `"commit" => "Foo"` or `"commit" => "Bar"`.
However, if the form is using unobtrusive javascript to make it an AJAX request:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}, {:remote => true}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
... then the parameters do not carry the submit control which was used. This is because the function `callRemote` in `rails.js` uses `serializeArray` on the form; but `serializeArray` doesn't take account of the control used to submit the form.
I have patched my local app by making use of `originalEvent`, but I have no means of using Git (my corporate firewall blocks the SSH port). How can I get my patch considered?
ticket.original-body-html:
(Rails 3.0.0)

Consider a simple view:

<%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}) do %>
  <%= submit_tag "Foo" %>
  <%= submit_tag "Bar" %>
<% end %>

When this is submitted (by normal POST), the parameters includes "commit" => "Foo" or "commit" => "Bar".

However, if the form is using unobtrusive javascript to make it an AJAX request:

<%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}, {:remote => true}) do %>
  <%= submit_tag "Foo" %>
  <%= submit_tag "Bar" %>
<% end %>

... then the parameters do not carry the submit control which was used. This is because the function callRemote in rails.js uses serializeArray on the form; but serializeArray doesn't take account of the control used to submit the form.

I have patched my local app by making use of originalEvent, but I have no means of using Git (my corporate firewall blocks the SSH port). How can I get my patch considered?

version.body:
(Rails 3.0.0)
Consider a simple view:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
When this is submitted (by normal POST), the parameters includes `"commit" => "Foo"` or `"commit" => "Bar"`.
However, if the form is using unobtrusive javascript to make it an AJAX request:
@@@ ruby <%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}, {:remote => true}) do %> <%= submit_tag "Foo" %> <%= submit_tag "Bar" %> <% end %> @@@
... then the parameters do not carry the submit control which was used. This is because the function `callRemote` in `rails.js` uses `serializeArray` on the form; but `serializeArray` doesn't take account of the control used to submit the form.
I have patched my local app by making use of `originalEvent`, but I have no means of using Git (my corporate firewall blocks the SSH port). How can I get my patch considered?
version.body-html:
(Rails 3.0.0)

Consider a simple view:

<%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}) do %>
  <%= submit_tag "Foo" %>
  <%= submit_tag "Bar" %>
<% end %>

When this is submitted (by normal POST), the parameters includes "commit" => "Foo" or "commit" => "Bar".

However, if the form is using unobtrusive javascript to make it an AJAX request:

<%= form_tag({:action => 'debug'}, {:remote => true}) do %>
  <%= submit_tag "Foo" %>
  <%= submit_tag "Bar" %>
<% end %>

... then the parameters do not carry the submit control which was used. This is because the function callRemote in rails.js uses serializeArray on the form; but serializeArray doesn't take account of the control used to submit the form.

I have patched my local app by making use of originalEvent, but I have no means of using Git (my corporate firewall blocks the SSH port). How can I get my patch considered?
version.title: Remote forms with multiple submit controls don't report which submit was used, under Unobtrusive JavaScript

version.body:
Is this in the prototype or jquery version of rails.js?
It appears to be fixed in the prototype version: https://github.com/rails/prototype-ujs/commit/f60d60dddcf0dd1f1ae4537b7d25ddaa89b9250d
If you want to make a patch but you are behind a firewall then you can use a [http clone url](https://github.com/rails/rails.git) and submit a patch as described in the [contributor guide](https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/sending-patches).
version.body-html:
Is this in the prototype or jquery version of rails.js?

It appears to be fixed in the prototype version:
https://github.com/rails/prototype-ujs/commit/f60d60dddcf0dd1f1ae45...

If you want to make a patch but you are behind a firewall then you can use a http clone url and submit a patch as described in the contributor guide.

version.title: Remote forms with multiple submit controls don't report which submit was used, under Unobtrusive JavaScript

version.body:
Patch file below. Apologies for the patch comment; I had to change my author details post-commit.
I'm not very experienced with JavaScript, so it's entirely possible this is a horrible way to fix the problem. I also don't understand the test-suite enough to update the tests, I'm afraid. Still, for what it's worth, here's the patch.
version.body-html:
Patch file below. Apologies for the patch comment; I had to change my author details post-commit.

I'm not very experienced with JavaScript, so it's entirely possible this is a horrible way to fix the problem. I also don't understand the test-suite enough to update the tests, I'm afraid. Still, for what it's worth, here's the patch.

version.title: Remote forms with multiple submit controls don't report which submit was used, under Unobtrusive JavaScript

version.body: Neeraj - a quick check with FireBug confirms what I was trying to workaround with the `originalEvent`; `e.target` is the *form* element, not the *submit* control.
version.body-html: Neeraj - a quick check with FireBug confirms what I was trying to workaround with the originalEvent; e.target is the form element, not the submit control.

why is the priority low for this? it seems like a major bug to me.
